page.title: 12RAILWAY AT BISHOPS LYDEARD
page.content: The railway first came to Bishops Lydeard in 1862 when a broad guauge line ran from Taunton to Watchet.In 1882 the gauge was changed and the line extended northwards to Minehead and at Taunton linked to the main Great Western Railway network.After serving the village well it was closed in 1971.However 5 years later it was purchased by the West Somerset Railway Company with help from Somerset County Council.There are now regular steam and diesel services throughout the year along the 20 miles between Bishops Lydeard and Minehead,being the longest independant railway in Great Britain.The track between Bishops Lydeard and Taunton has been retained in the hope that one day trains will again be able to link up with the main network instead of having to travel the 5 miles to Taunton by bus.
